title: Kap Choeng district
text:
Kap Choeng (, ) is a district ("<a href="amphoe">amphoe</a>") in the southern part of <a href="Surin%20province">Surin province</a>, northeastern <a href="Thailand">Thailand</a>.
History.
The village of Ban Kap Choeng is about 200 years old. It was originally under sub-district ("<a href="tambon">tambon</a>") Dan of <a href="Sangkha%20district">Sangkha district</a>, but 1937 was moved to Tambon Nong Yai, <a href="Prasat%20district">Prasat district</a>. In 1964, it became part of the newly created sub-district of Kap Choeng.
On 25 May 1975, Tambon Kap Choeng and Bakdai were combined to form a minor district ("<a href="king%20amphoe">king amphoe</a>"). Tambon Khok Klang was created in 1976, Tambons Dan and Khu Tan were transferred to it from Sangkha in 1977. On 20 March 1979, Kap Choeng was upgraded to a full district.
Geography.
Neighboring districts are (from the west clockwise): <a href="Phanom%20Dong%20Rak%20district">Phanom Dong Rak</a>, <a href="Prasat%20district">Prasat</a> and <a href="Sangkha%20district">Sangkha</a> of Surin Province. To the south is <a href="Oddar%20Meancheay">Oddar Meancheay</a> of <a href="Cambodia">Cambodia</a>.
The southern part of this district is in the <a href="D%C3%A2ngr%C3%AAk%20Mountains">Dângrêk Mountains</a>. An international <a href="border%20crossing">border crossing</a> into <a href="Cambodia">Cambodia</a> is called the Chong Chom Checkpoint which is located in Dan village in the southern part of this district. The checkpoint on the Cambodian side is called <a href="O%20Smach">O Smach</a> International Checkpoint in <a href="Samraong%20Municipality">Samraong Municipality</a>, <a href="Oddar%20Meanchey%20province">Oddar Meanchey province</a>.
Administration.
The district is divided into six sub-districts ("<a href="tambon">tambon</a>s"), which are further subdivided into 91 villages ("<a href="muban">muban</a>s"). There are no municipal ("<a href="thesaban">thesaban</a>") areas. There are six tambon administrative organizations (TAO).
